quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 10 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 10.8: Applications of Trig Equations
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Modeling and solving real-world periodic problems

questions.question: The height of a tide is modeled by $h(t) = 4\cos(\frac{\pi}{6}t) + 5$. To find when the tide is exactly 7 feet, what is the first algebraic step?
questions.explanation: You must isolate the cosine term by subtracting 5 and then dividing by 4.

questions.question: A weight on a spring oscillates according to $d(t) = 10\sin(2t)$. At what value of $t$ (in the first cycle) does the weight first reach 5 cm?
In a Ferris wheel model $H(t) = 20\sin(\frac{\pi}{30}t - \frac{\pi}{2}) + 25$, what does the constant 25 usually represent?
options: The height of the center of the wheel (axle).
The starting position of the rider.
questions.explanation: The vertical shift in a trig model represents the midline, which for a Ferris wheel is the center height.

questions.question: If a seasonal temperature model is $T(m) = 20\sin(\frac{\pi}{6}m) + 60$, why might there be two months ($m$) where the temperature is 70 degrees?
options: The temperature rises in spring and falls in autumn.
The sine function only has one solution per year.
It is a calculation error; there is only one solution.
questions.explanation: Sine waves hit most values twice in a single period (rising and falling stages).

questions.question: Solve $120\sin(120\pi t) = 60$ for the smallest positive $t$.
When solving application problems, why is it important to know the period of the function?
options: To find all solutions within a specific timeframe (like 24 hours).
questions.explanation: The period tells you how often the cycle repeats, helping you find all relevant times a value occurs.

questions.question: A sound wave is modeled by $P(t) = 0.5\cos(440\pi t)$. What is the frequency of this note in Hz?
True or False: In a real-world model $y = A\sin(Bt - C) + D$, the value of $y$ can never exceed $D + A$.
questions.explanation: True. The maximum value of a sine wave is the midline ($D$) plus the amplitude ($A$).

questions.question: A light buoy moves up and down. If $h(t) = 2\sin(t) = 0$, the buoy is at its 'rest' position. How many times does it hit this position in $2\pi$ seconds?
questions.explanation: On the closed interval $[0, 2\pi]$, sine is zero at the start, middle, and end of the period.

questions.question: If a calculator gives $t = -0.5$ for a time-based application, how do you find the first positive time?
options: Add the period of the function to the negative result.
questions.explanation: Adding the period finds the next 'occurrence' of that same position in the next cycle.

scoreMessages.90: Application Ace! You can translate math into the real world.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Keep an eye on the period when solving for time!
scoreMessages.50: Remember to isolate the trig term before attempting to solve for 't'.
scoreMessages.0: Review the components of a sinusoidal model (Amplitude, Period, Midline).
